The Pamir Mountains have played an important role in the religious landscape of Tajikistan, particularly in relation to Islam. The region of Pamirs is often referred to as the "Roof of the World" and is home to the Ismaili Muslims, a sect of Shia Islam. The Pamir Mountains have acted as a natural barrier to religious and cultural influences from surrounding regions, leading to the development of a distinct Ismaili identity in the area.

The Ismaili Muslims in Tajikistan are followers of His Highness Prince Karim Aga Khan IV, who is the spiritual leader of the Shia Ismaili Muslims worldwide. The Aga Khan Development Network has invested heavily in the Pamir Mountains region, launching various development projects, including education, health care, and tourism, supporting the Ismaili community in the region.

The Pamir Mountains continue to play a significant role in the religious and cultural identity of the Ismaili community. The Aga Khan Foundation has funded various restoration projects for religious monuments and artifacts in the region, including the Ismaili holy site of the Ostoni Quduq pilgrimage complex.

Overall, the Pamir Mountains have acted as a natural barrier for religious and cultural influences in Tajikistan, leading to the development of a unique Ismaili Muslim identity in the region. The Aga Khan Foundation has continued to provide support for the Ismaili community in the Pamir Mountains, strengthening the religion's role in the region's identity.
